Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Measuring RNA Tertiary Contacts in SARS-CoV2
Award.AbstractNarration:
The genome of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is encoded in RNA. This award funds studies by Dr. Victoria J. DeRose at the University of Oregon in Eugene, OR to characterize the three-dimensional structure of the viral RNA. Dr. DeRose uses platinum compounds that chemically attach to RNA bases to determine distances separating different parts of the RNA. Combining the distance information with computer predictions leads to a picture of the SARS-CoV-2 RNA genome. The impact of the project on society is to identify potential target sites in the viral genome, which provides further leads for the development of therapeutic interventions against the COVID-19 pandemic.Results from this project may impact the ability to understand and develop therapeutics targeting SARS-CoV2 by providing information required to accurately model its RNA structures. Methods developed in this project may be applicable to the next emergent virus. Importantly, this project will support PhD students in research that applies chemical biology to fundamental science with immediate application to a major global crisis.

The goal of this project is to enable three-dimensional modeling of SARS-CoV2 RNA structures by measuring tertiary contacts through chemical crosslinking. Platinum (II) crosslinking reagents are used to obtain a library of RNA-RNA interactions in and between SARS-CoV2 RNA domains. The resulting long-range connectivity maps provide distance constraints to complement computational and NMR spectroscopic studies for the derivation of three-dimensional models of the viral RNAs. These models are compared to the RNA in solution and in mammalian cells, helping to expedite small molecule targeting of RNA processes that are critical to virus function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA virus outbreaks, such as caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), can cause global disruption. These viruses contain an RNA genome that is decoded in the host cell, beginning a program that hijacks the host cell to replicate the virus.  RNA viral genomes have coding regions that code for the viral proteins that will be made by the host. In addition to these coding regions, RNA genomes contain non-coding sequences with 3-dimensional structures that are recognized by host and virus proteins, and that are critical for function. Modern sequencing techniques can rapidly provide the sequence of viral RNA genomes, but the sequence is not sufficient to predict the 3-dimensional folded form of the RNA. Predicting and testing the 3-dimensional folded form of the genome requires additional information that is not yet available in standard sequencing methods. Knowing three-dimensional structures helps to understand the function of the viral genome, and also to determine regions to target with RNA-directed inhibitors. 

The goal of this project is to gain critical information about the 3-dimensional structure of the viral RNA by using small molecules that can crosslink RNA sequences that are brought close together in folded structures, and then isolate and identify those crosslinked regions. To increase the breadth of structural information, two small molecule reagents were used in these studies that have different requirements for crosslinked sequences. Platinum(II) compounds that have two exchangeable coordination sites are used to target purines (guanine or adenine nucleobases) that are in close proximity in the folded RNA. By contrast, the organic molecule psoralen crosslinks neighboring uridine nucleobases. These two reagents are expected to capture different regions that are brought into proximity in the folded RNA structure. Both reagents were modified with ‘clickable’ azide handles that allowed isolation of the crosslinked regions of RNA. The 5-prime-untranslated region (5-UTR) of the SARS-CoV-2 genome contains several domains important to the viral life cycle including the region where host ribosomes bind to translate viral proteins.  To create a test system for viral RNA structure in cells, a new reporter system was created that encodes the 5-UTR of SARS CoV-2 connected to a gene coding for a bioluminescent protein (luciferase). This plasmid was transfected into mammalian BSR T7/5 cells that produce the T7 RNA polymerase that will make RNA from the reporter construct. Cells making the reporter SARS CoV-2 5-UTR RNA were treated with two RNA crosslinking reagents, and the crosslinked RNAs isolated and prepared for high-throughput sequencing and analysis. These results will be compared with crosslinks obtained from same RNA sequence folded outside of the cell, to see if the cellular environment changes the three-dimensional structure of the RNA. The results from this analysis will be published, and the reporter plasmid will be deposited into GenBank as a novel reagent for researchers. This project has supported training for multiple students, including the foundation of two PhD theses. Three undergraduate students also received valuable research experience in RNA biochemistry and biotechnology.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2024
Modified by: Victoria J Derose

    SARS CoV-2 5'UTR reporter and crosslinking analysis

These viruses contain an RNA genome that is decoded in the host cell, beginning a program that hijacks the host cell to replicate the virus. RNA viral genomes have coding regions that code for the viral proteins that will be made by the host. In addition to these coding regions, RNA genomes contain non-coding sequences with 3-dimensional structures that are recognized by host and virus proteins, and that are critical for function. Modern sequencing techniques can rapidly provide the sequence of viral RNA genomes, but the sequence is not sufficient to predict the 3-dimensional folded form of the RNA. Predicting and testing the 3-dimensional folded form of the genome requires additional information that is not yet available in standard sequencing methods. Knowing three-dimensional structures helps to understand the function of the viral genome, and also to determine regions to target with RNA-directed inhibitors.
